header_summary:
Ava Chow announced the release of Bitcoin Core version 28.1, introducing new features, bug fixes, and performance enhancements, urging users to report issues via GitHub and join the announcement list for updates. This version, compatible with major operating systems, emphasizes improvements in peer-to-peer configurations and various system adjustments, with detailed guidance for upgrading from older versions and specific instructions for macOS users. Contributors to this version are acknowledged for their collaborative efforts in development and translation [Bitcoin Core's official website](https://bitcoincore.org/bin/bitcoin-core-28.1).

Jameson Lopp raised concerns about the reliability of timestamp data in Bitcoin transactions, specifically addressing a flaw in transaction prioritization based on nLockTime that could be exploited by adversaries. This highlights a potential vulnerability in the proposed system, suggesting a need for further discussion to secure transaction timestamp integrity and prevent systemic gaming [source URL](https://gnusha.org/pi/bitcoindev/f1a0153b-3142-4e01-a68e-92c458762b89@dashjr.org/T/#md45faf348c4d6ff9b7a87019770ad6967382bd2a).

Yuval Kogman critiqued the misconceptions surrounding privacy mechanisms in technologies, particularly focusing on the limitations of wabisabi credentials and the vulnerabilities of the Wasabi protocols to DoS attacks. The discourse extends to the auditing practices and the ethical implications of exploiting privacy, emphasizing the necessity for comprehensive security measures and ethical considerations in the development of privacy-preserving technologies [source URL](https://gnusha.org/pi/bitcoindev/CAAQdECAg5W4a9_386FeGWBZnv7zje4gmXtAMcC8scWq_o2dEwg@mail.gmail.com/T/#mc443b9fe5281ff0e052fbf07ef8658cb9f58e8b3).

Antoine Riard announced his intention to take legal action against Matthew Corallo over governance and respect issues within open-source software projects, marking a significant disagreement between two prominent contributors. This dispute, rooted in differing views on leadership and project contribution, underscores the complexities of collaboration and governance in the open-source community. Riard's decision to pursue litigation highlights the broader implications of such conflicts for the principles of decentralization and governance within open-source projects [source URL](https://delvingbitcoin.org/t/code-of-conduct-violation-banning-antoine-riard-for-3-months/1254/3).

recent_posts.title: Deterministic tx selection for censorship resistance
recent_posts.summary:
- Braidpool, akin to Bitcoin, mirrors its transaction decision-making complexity.
- Upgrading nodes and potential hard forks in Braidpool highlight systemic management challenges.
- There's a plan to allow limited non-committed bitcoin transactions in share-chain blocks.

recent_posts.title: How to linearize your cluster
recent_posts.summary:
- The discussion analyzes optimizing transaction fees by selecting high fee rate subsets.
- It introduces a lemma indicating a unique optimal set, $pot$, based on inclusion/exclusion criteria.
- The analysis concludes with a proof supporting optimization within blockchain structural constraints.

active_posts.title: Mandatory Inclusion of Old Transactions in Blocks
active_posts.summary:
- The proposal mandates Bitcoin miners to include 0.1% oldest transactions in blocks.
- It aims to prevent mining centralization and ensure democratic transaction processing.
- The measure promotes fairness and censorship resistance in the Bitcoin network.

active_posts.title: Reiterating centralized coinjoin (Wasabi & Samourai) deanonymization attacks
active_posts.summary:
- Vulnerabilities in Wasabi & GingerWallet and CoinJoin protocols reveal significant deanonymization risks.
- Fundamental protocol flaws allow malicious coordinators to fully deanonymize transactions.
- Economic incentives and poor design choices fail to ensure user privacy and financial security.

active_posts.title: Bitcoin Core 28.1 Released
active_posts.summary:
- Bitcoin Core version 28.1 is now available, featuring new updates and bug fixes.
- Upgrade requires shutting down older versions, with support for old wallets maintained.
- Significant changes include adjustments to P2P configurations and port management.

active_posts.title: Great Consensus Cleanup Revival
active_posts.summary:
- The proposal highlights Bitcoin protocol vulnerabilities, suggesting improvements for security and performance.
- It aims to fix the timewarp issue and mitigate risks from non-SegWit transactions and small merkle roots.
- Community debate arises around block size reduction, reflecting concerns on scalability and efficiency.

active_posts.title: PPLNS with job declaration
active_posts.summary:
- The SV2 extension enhances transparency and fairness in mining pool payouts.
- Miners can select transactions, impacting fee structures, based on the PPLNS system.
- The project seeks contributions for refinement, with details on GitHub for review.

active_posts.title: Ecash TIDES using Cashu and Stratum v2
active_posts.summary:
- Integrating BDHKE into Stratum v2 enhances privacy and auditability for small payouts.
- The process involves miners submitting shares via updated `block_keysets` for reward assessments.
- The proposal includes using Cashu for spending conditions and enhancing ASIC efficiency.

today_in_history_posts.title: Proof-of-Stake Bitcoin Sidechains
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- The writer proposes a proof-of-mainstake sidechain design without altering the Bitcoin mainchain.
- They suggest embedding sidechain block headers in the mainchain via transactions authorized by stakers.
- Mainchain-to-sidechain transfers and staking involve special scripts, while withdrawal mechanisms are determined by the sidechain.

today_in_history_posts.title: Lightning and the semantic web
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Melvin is integrating the Lightning Network with Solid to enhance user data control.
- He plans to create an ontology for porting Lightning concepts to the semantic web.
- Melvin seeks collaboration and existing work on creating this ontology.

today_in_history_posts.title: Thoughts on scaling and consensus changes (2023)
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Bitcoin's scalability aims for 1 billion weekly users through 50,000 off-chain "bitcoin banks."- Semi-trusted entities interconnected for liquidity pose a balance between affordability and security.
- Development focuses on Layer 2 protocols and market pressures for regulatory compliance and security.
